metadata.title: Achilles Tendon Rupture
description: Achilles tendon rupture is a tear of the AT that typically occurs as a result of chronic degeneration of the tendon combined with mechanical stress such as jumping(3)
The site of AT rupture is usually 3 to 6 cm proximal to the insertion of the AT, the location of its poorest blood supply(4)
Kuwada classification of AT ruptures (23) –Type I – partial tear –Type II – complete rupture with defect no greater than 3 cm –Type III –defect  is 3–6 cm –Type IV – defect is greater than 6 cm
The nonoperative treatment option for acute AT rupture involves immobilization of the ankle and foot in a cast, cast-boot,  or splint for 6 weeks or more(4)

Operative treatment includes open or arthroscopic (minimally invasive or percutaneous) repair followed by immobilization in a cast for up to 3 weeks, followed by a removable cast with adjustable ankle motion(4)

Conservative treatment is associated with more chance of re-rupture  and is recommended for patients who are sedentary and patients at higher risk for wound healing problems, a complication that occurs in approximately 5% of surgical patients(4)
Operative treatment is preferred for patients who wish to return to sporting activities(7)
This Clinical Review focuses on the role of functional rehabilitation after treatment for acute AT rupture

ICD-10 codes.M66.2: spontaneous rupture of extensor tendons (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Patient may identify a snapping/popping sensation with the injury(3)
Severe pain, hematoma, and swelling usually develop within several hours of the injury. Pain is not always an initial presenting symptom(3)
A palpable gap or sulcus in AT continuity(3)
Unilateral calf weakness and an inability to raise the heel when bearing weight on affected leg(3)
Flat-footed  gait pattern, like walking on soft beach sand,(1) with reduced push-off  during terminal stance

Patients typically present to physical therapy within 2 weeks of rupture, immobilized in a rigid cast or functional splint, bearing weight as tolerated and using crutches Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Contact patient’s physician immediately if DVT is suspected due to presence of unilateral edema, erythema, tenderness, and positive Homans’ sign

causes: AT rupture typically is caused by a sudden forceful contraction of the gastrocnemius-  soleus muscle with an abruptdeceleration that commonly occur in activities such as jumping or when landing(2)

Frequent causes–Abrupt, forced dorsiflexion on a plantar flexed ankle, such as landing from a jump or a misstep(3)–Abrupt push-off  on a load-bearing  forefoot(3)–Long-standing  tendinopathy (22)–Intratendinous degenerative conditions (22)
A recent increase in training intensity(3)
pathogenesis: Mechanism of injury typically is mechanical overload during an eccentric contraction of the gastrocsoleusmuscle(4)

Achilles tendinopathy/tendinosis predisposes to weakness and spontaneous rupture. The etiology likely involves poortissue quality due to repetitive microtrauma from improper training techniques, although intrinsic biochemical factors (andsometimes drugs such as systemic corticosteroids and fluoroquinolone antibiotics) may contribute to the tendinopathy(3)
Neurogenic inflammation with the presence of calcitonin gene-related  peptide and substance P (22)
Histological findings show thickening, fibrinous adhesions within the tendon (22)
risk factors: Spontaneous AT rupture is most common in men aged 30 to 50 years who participate in sports recreationally(2,3,4)
High-risk  sports involve a significant amount of running and jumping(4)–Basketball–Soccer–Softball–Tennis/racket sports

Other risk factors that have been proposed–Use of fluoroquinolones, especially in combination with corticosteroids (22)–Use of quinolone antibiotics (22)–Inflammatory arthritides (22)–Use of oral or systemic corticosteroids (22)–Poor conditioning (22)–Overexertion (22)–Recent changes in athletic training schedule(3)–Lower-leg  malalignment (e.g.,tibialvarum, overpronation, cavusfoot)(3)

overall contraindications precautions: Consider prior use of fluoroquinolone antibiotics as a red flag for increased risk of rupture/re-rupture(3)

Follow the physician’s protocol regarding weight-bearing Conservative treatment frequently requires cessation of weight-bearing  activities, casting, and crutches for ambulation –Researchers in Denmark compared non-weight-bearing  for 6 weeks to full weight-bearing  from day 1 in a blinded RCT involving 60 patients with AT rupture(8) -The primary outcome measure was the AT Total Rupture Score after one year. Secondary outcome measures included heel-rise  work, health-related  QOL, and re-rupture  rate  -The only significant difference between the groups was better health-related  QOL in the weight-bearing  group, suggesting that immediate weight-bearing  can be recommended as an option in the nonoperative treatment of AT rupture
If patient is seen through direct access or patient is referred with another diagnosis and AT rupture is suspected, immediately refer to physician
Monitor postsurgical patients for signs and symptoms of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and report immediately to the treating physician
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

contraindications precautions to examina: Contact patient’s physician immediately if DVT is suspected due to presence of unilateral edema, erythema, tenderness, and positive Homans’ sign

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury -Patients may have no prior history of calf or heel pathology -Did specific movements just prior to “pop” or “snap” of tendon involve sudden eccentric dorsiflexion under loaded plantar flexion?(4) -Was ambulation impaired more by calf weakness than pain?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Acute AT rupture is managed conservatively with immobilization in a cast for natural mending or is surgically repaired(4) Conservative management generally is recommended for(4) sedentary patients patients at risk for poor healing of incision patients who are considered high-risk  surgical candidates Surgical intervention involves end-to-end  repair of the severed tendon lengths. Tissue grafts may be used for bridging the gap and to provide a scaffold on which new tissue grows. The tendons of the flexor hallucislongus, plantaris, and peroneus brevis often are used for augmentation.(9)Surgery is generally recommended for(4) active patients when there has been more than 2 weeks from time of rupture to time of assessment active patients to restore normal function when the injury is a re-rupture  or there is high risk of re-rupture
course of treatment.medications: Analgesics may be prescribed for pain
diagnostic tests completed: The diagnosis is based primarily on clinical examination
MRI is extremely sensitive in determining if some tendon remains in continuity(4)
Diffusion tensor imaging is a noninvasive imaging technique that can be used to describe the structure and characteristics of a postoperative Achilles tendon repair(11)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for Achilles tendinopathy or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. Have any lower extremity malalignment issues been diagnosed in the patient? Has patient been prescribed shoe inserts or orthotics?

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Are there any activities or positions that aggravate or alleviate symptoms?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (a.m., mid-day,  p.m., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/nightDocument the use of any supplemental oxygen. Does the patient smoke?
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., signs and symptoms of DVT, marked increase in swelling) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __ -If Yes, describe ________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Is there a history of Achilles pathology or trauma (diagnosis, X-rays, treatment)? Recurrence is common, especially with nonsurgical treatment(3,4)
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Document other health problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs). Use of fluoroquinolone antibiotics, especially in combination with corticosteroids, increases the risk of AT rupture(3,22)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient participate in sports that involve running or jumping? Does patient plan on returning to his/her sport?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Patients, including those postoperative, typically present to physical therapy within 2 weeks of rupture, immobilized in a rigid cast or functional splint and using crutches. Functional limitations commonly include impaired gait and stair-climbing  and the inability to participate in sports
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.) The tests and measures performed will depend on the medical management of the patient, the time of injury and/or surgery, and the physician’s orders and rehabilitation protocol, if applicable
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Measure calf circumference for swelling or atrophy, as indicated. Measure figure-8 ankle circumference for swelling. Compare to uninvolved limb
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess for proper fit, care, and use of crutches or cane, walker, or wheelchair
relevant tests and measures.balance: Per weight-bearing  restrictions, assess static and dynamic balance in standing (flat-footed,  on toes, and tandem stance) and with perturbations. Use Functional Reach Test, Berg Balance Scale, or Tinetti test for objective balance measurement, as appropriate for stage of rehabilitation
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Assess weight-bearing  status. After removal of cast and with clearance from physician for weight-bearing,  compare height of 1-leg standing heel raise to uninvolved side; the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test can be used for objective measurement
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Patients usually demonstrate a flat-footed  or calcaneus gait pattern, with inability to rise up onto ball of foot. Assess push-off in the terminal stance phase of level walking. Assess for proper gait mechanics and weight-bearing status with assistive device; the Functional Gait Assessment (FGA) can be used for objective measurementAssess joint accessory motion of talocrural and subtalar joints; restrictions may be present after immobilization
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Initially, assess isometric strength of ankle plantar flexors and progress to dynamic strength testing according to rehabilitation protocol or stage of healing. Measure calf circumference for atrophy. Compare to unaffected side. Expect significant plantar flexion weakness. Scan strength of involved lower extremity at knee and hip joints –Results from a 7-year  follow-up  study of Swedish patients after AT rupture indicated that calf strength and endurance deficits were still present(14)  –Results from a study of soleus strength after AT rupture indicated that patients who received conservative management had more soleus atrophy than patients who received surgical treatment(17) -Atrophy was assessed by MRI to measure muscle volumes or fatty degeneration -One aspect that the authors noted was the difference in the mean Achilles tendon length, which was 19 mm longer after nonsurgical treatment than after the surgical treatment of AT ruptures
relevant tests and measures.posture: Assess for compensatory pelvic shift to reduce weight on injured leg in standing and walking. Assess subtalar neutral in non-weight-bearing
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess stiffness/flexibility of calf muscles. If appropriate, assess spontaneous plantar flexion in unsupported prone lying (usually absent in complete rupture). Assess active and passive ROM of ankle plantar flexion (both usually reduced after rupture) and dorsiflexion (both increased acutely in complete rupture, but then reduced with development of inflexibility in the healing calf-tendon  complex). Assess ankle inversion and eversion for limitations. If appropriate, assess for excessive pronation at subtalar joint
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Assess sensation in the distribution of the sural nerve to ensure intact function; nerve injury may occur during surgery. Sural nerve entrapment is greater in percutaneous AT repair vs. open surgical repair
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Thompson (calf squeeze) test – examiner squeezes the calf just distal to the area of maximal girth with patient in prone lying or kneeling on a chair with ankle unsupported. With an intact AT the foot will plantarflex. Test is positive, indicating discontinuity of AT, if loss of plantar flexion is noted compared to uninvolved side.(3) The test has 96% sensitivity and 93% specificity(10) -Cadaveric studies suggest that the Thompson test might not be useful for diagnosing partial AT ruptures(10) –Matles test – patient is prone with knees flexed to 90˚; if the injured foot falls to neutral or a dorsiflexed position, the test is positive for a ruptured AT(3) –Lower Extremity Functional Scale (LEFS). This questionnaire was found to be more sensitive for detecting change than the Short Form–36  Health Survey

contraindications precautions: Hypertension  cold can lead to an increase in blood pressure
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Avoid placement over superficial nerves for extended periods (> 1 hour)
Cold may be counterproductive if being used to facilitate muscle relaxation and reduce pain in patients who do not tolerate the modality
other: Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Reduced functional mobility, strength, and ROM, impaired gait mechanics, and deficits in functional status, including balance and posture Rule out  (3,22) Achilles bursitis Ankle fracture Ankle impingement syndrome Ankle osteoarthritis Ankle sprain Calf injuries Calcaneofibular ligament injury Calcaneus fractures DVT Exertional compartment syndrome Fascial tears Gastrocsoleus muscle strain or rupture Haglund deformity Psoriatic arthritis Reiter syndrome Retrocalcaneal bursitis Ruptured Baker cyst Syndesmosis Talofibular ligament injury treatment(16) -200 patients (99 operative, 101 nonoperative) aged between 18 and 65 years treated in New Zealand Authors of a 2015 retrospective study conducted between 2005 and 2014 (270 cases) compared surgical procedures of percutaneous Achilles repair system (PARS) versus open technique and found that 98% of patients treated with PARS  were able to return to baseline activities within 5 months compared to the 82% of patients treated with the open technique procedure(13)
prognosis: Prognosis for recovery is good after either conservative or surgical treatment(3,4)
Outcomes for delayed surgical repair are worse than for early repair(3)

Authors of a systematic review and network meta-analysis  of 2,060 patients with an achilles tendon rupture found that minimally invasive surgery combined with accelerated rehabilitation was superior to other treatment methods with respect to complications. Patients who received nonoperative care with early immobilization had the highest risk of complications (21)
Chronic Achilles tendon rupture of at least 3 cm separation is likely to result in poor functional mobility and surgical management is recommended(12)
Authors of a study conducted in 2018 found that patients may have deficits in calf muscle strength and endurance that remain 7 years following Achilles tendon rupture (19)
other considerations: Authors of a 2017 systematic review and meta-analysis  comparing conservative management to surgical treatment concluded that surgical treatment was better at preventing re-rupture  than conservative management(15) –Eight RCTs with a total of 762 patients were analyzed in the meta-analysis –There was no difference found between techniques for incidence of deep venous thrombosis, the number who returned to sport, ankle ROM (dorsiflexion, plantar flexion), Achilles Tendon Total Rupture Score, or physical activity scale

The decision to treat surgically (open or percutaneously) or nonoperatively (immobilization with a rigid cast or more mobile functional bracing) is influenced by many patient characteristics and conditions as well as treatment options –Results from a 10-year  follow-up  after AT rupture comparing Achilles Tendon Total Rupture Score (ATRS) as a functional measure after operative and nonoperative treatment of acute Achilles tendon rupture using an identical rehabilitation program of functional bracing indicated there was no difference between operative and nonoperative
treatment summary: Early functional mobilization generally improves tendon elongation during the early phases of recovery (20)

Various treatment protocols/guidelines exist, including –conventional postsurgical care following primary AT repair(2) -Foot and ankle are immobilized for at least 6 weeks -Patient is non-weight-bearing  during immobilization period -After immobilization period, patient generally is given a controlled ankle motion (CAM) brace and active ROM is begun -Typically, after 12 weeks the brace is discontinued barring complications -Note: For patients who undergo reconstruction with tendon graft for a chronic AT rupture, all time frames usually are extended by at least 2 weeks –early mobilization following primary repair of an acute rupture(2) -Types of splinting or bracing differ; however, weight-bearing  restrictions usually are imposed for 6 weeks -During this time of protected healing the splint or brace may be removed only for incision care or prescribed non-weight-bearing  exercise -ROM is initiated within 2 weeks after surgery (following certain parameters) and often using a functional brace or splint -Partial weight-bearing  with crutches and splint or brace as tolerated usually is permitted soon after surgery -Typically, when patient can walk on level surfaces pain-free  (at week 8 to 10) the splint or brace is discontinued

Functional rehabilitation incorporating early weight-bearing  is considered a safe alternative to immobilization following treatment for Achilles tendon rupture, resulting in better early functional outcomes (18) –Based on an RCT study conducted in the United Kingdom –One hundred forty patients with Achilles tendon rupture were randomized to receive traditional nonoperative management (n = 71) or accelerated functional rehabilitation with walking boot (n = 69) –Those in the nonoperative management group were casted with the ankle in full equinus position and were asked to maintain non-weight-bearing.  After 4 weeks, patients were recasted and placed in a semi-equinus  position for another 4 weeks while maintaining non-weight-bearing  status. After another 4 weeks, patients wererecasted with the ankle in neutral position and were advised to fully weight bear. After 2 weeks the cast was removed and patients were started on physical therapy. Active plantar flexion started at week 10 –Patients in the accelerated functional group were placed in an Ossur Rebound walking boot with a 3-cm  internal heel raise that was worn continuously (including bed) and were immediately given full-weight-bearing  status with use of assistive device as needed. After 4 weeks, the heel rise was reduced to 1.5 cm for 2 weeks. After 2 weeks, the walking boot was repositioned with no heel rise. No ROM exercises were performed while the patients were in the walking boot. The boot was removed after 8 weeks and physical therapy was initiated. Active plantar flexion started at week 8 –Results show that at 6-month  follow-up,  those in the walking boot reported better outcomes on the Short Musculoskeletal Function Assessment (SMFA) dysfunction index, Achilles Tendon Total Rupture Score, and Foot and Ankle Questionnaire Core score. After 1-year  follow-up,  there were no significant differences in outcome scores . recovered > % of strength in ankle plant: Static 1-leg  heel raise, height and duration of heel raise
Number of full heel raises completed
restored balance: Balance assessment (Functional Reach Test, Berg Balance Scale, Tinetti test)

maintenance or prevention: Varying exercises may decrease risk. Alternate high-impact  sports, such as running, with low-impact  sports, such as walking, swimming, and biking. Avoid activities that excessively stress the AT, such as jumping and hillrunning
Choose running surfaces carefully. Avoid running on hard or slippery surfaces. Wear properly fitting shoes with adequate cushioning in the heels
Increase training volume slowly (e.g., increase the distance, duration, and frequency of training by no more than 10% each week)(6)
